de.lmu.ifi.dbs.jfeaturelib.features

Class MeanIntensityLocalBinaryPatterns

  • java.lang.Object
    • de.lmu.ifi.dbs.jfeaturelib.features.AbstractFeatureDescriptor
      • de.lmu.ifi.dbs.jfeaturelib.features.MeanIntensityLocalBinaryPatterns
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Descriptor, FeatureDescriptor

    public class MeanIntensityLocalBinaryPatterns
extends AbstractFeatureDescriptor
    Patch-based local binary patterns.

    Constructs histogram of binary patterns based on comparing the mean intensity of the 8-neighborhood of each pixel Ni in the patch to the mean intensity of the 8-neighborhood around the pixel in the center NC. Each of the 8 mean intensities Ni is compared to the mean intensity NC in the center, if Ni is smaller than NC, Ni is assigned weight 0, else 1. The weights form a binary pattern by contactinating them in counter clockwise order, starting with the weight to the left of the pixel in the center.

    Example:
    Mean intensity patch: 

        |  2 | 25 | 32 |
    | 24 | 23 |  9 |
    | 19 | 99 | 13 |
    Weights: 
        | 0 | 1 | 1 |
    | 1 |   | 0 |
    | 0 | 1 | 0 |
    Binary pattern: 0b10100110

    All pixels part of the 2-pixel wide margin are not considered due to incomplete 8-neighborhoods of these pixels.

    References: 

    

    Author:
    
  
    sebp
    

    See Also:
    MeanPatchIntensityDescriptor

        getDescription
        

        public String getDescription()
        

        Description copied from interface: FeatureDescriptor
        

        Returns a short plain Text description about the Descriptor and the
 semantics of the double array obtained from FeatureDescriptor.getFeatures().

 May return null if no description is implemented - even though this
 should be avoided by any means.
        

        Returns:
        semantic description of getFeatures or null.

        run
        

        public void run(ij.process.ImageProcessor ip)
        

        Description copied from interface: Descriptor
        

        Start processing of this algorithm on the given image processor. Keep in
 mind that if the imageProcessor is changed, Supports.NoChanges must not
 be set.

 This is also the case even if only ImageProcessor.snapshot() is used.

        setHistogramRange
        

        public void setHistogramRange(double min,
                     double max)
        

        Set the minimum and maximum value that the histogram should consider.

 If both min and max are set to zero (default), limits are retrieved from data.
        

        Throws:
        

        IllegalArgumentException - if min > max
